comments:
Insurance 205 describes the concepts and techniques available to corporations, non-profit organizations, and other organizations in their efforts to manage pure risks. The costs associated with such pure risks as product liability, environmental impairments, property losses, work-related injuries, and employee benefits (e.g., pensions, health insurance, etc.) affect the daily management of organizations. Managers who make decisions without appropriate consideration of risk management issues can jeopardize the long-term survival of their organizations. The course examines a common set of techniques which can be used by managers in dealing with these problems, including risk assumption, prevention, diversification, and transfer via insurance and non-insurance market mechanisms. In turn, students learn to recognize that the institutional structure of the organization itself influence its own risks and their corresponding treatments.  The course is divided into three modules entitled The Theory of Risk, Human Capital Risk Management, and Corporate Risk Management.  Each section is taught by a different professor.

Most students felt that the course was “good.”  Several highlighted the overlap between INSR 205 and finance, microeconomics, and math courses that they had already taken.   Of these students, most disliked the repetition and felt that it would be better to “cut these repeated topics out and instead add unique material.” Students generally liked the modular format and having “three different professors to mix things up.”  A few students mentioned that the course was “quantitative” and “problem-based.”

Professor Doherty taught the third module.  Only two students commented specifically on Professor Doherty.  The first appreciated Professor Doherty’s effort “to influence audience participation,” but felt that he sometimes “asked really weak questions, merely to get students to wake up.”  This same student commented that Professor Doherty “skipped around his lectures a lot, and much of the material in the notes was never covered.”  A few other students also felt that the organization of the third module “could be improved.”  The second student commented that all the professors “were prepared for class and knew their material.”  This student also felt that Professor Doherty was “very interesting and engaging.”  While he sometimes “seemed to go to a higher level than what students were ready for, “ the student thought “he did a good job of connecting the theoretical and practical.”

Grading for the class is based entirely on three exams. There is one exam per module and the exams are not cumulative.  There are no prerequisites. INSR 205 fulfills the Organizational Environment requirement for Wharton undergrads.

Insurance 205 describes the concepts and techniques available to corporations, non-profit organizations, and other organizations in their efforts to manage pure risks. The costs associated with such pure risks as product liability, environmental impairments, property losses, work-related injuries, and employee benefits (e.g., pensions, health insurance, etc.) affect the daily management of organizations. Managers who make decisions without appropriate consideration of risk management issues can jeopardize the long-term survival of their organizations. The course examines a common set of techniques which can be used by managers in dealing with these problems, including risk assumption, prevention, diversification, and transfer via insurance and non-insurance market mechanisms. In turn, students learn to recognize that the institutional structure of the organization itself influence its own risks and their corresponding treatments.  The course is divided into three modules entitled The Theory of Risk, Human Capital Risk Management, and Corporate Risk Management.  Each section is taught by a different professor.

Most students felt that the course was “good.”  Several highlighted the overlap between INSR 205 and finance, microeconomics, and math courses that they had already taken.   Of these students, most disliked the repetition and felt that it would be better to “cut these repeated topics out and instead add unique material.” Students generally liked the modular format and having “three different professors to mix things up.”  A few students mentioned that the course was “quantitative” and “problem-based.”

Professor Nini taught module two.  Of the four students who commented specifically about Professor Nini, three were overwhelming positive and felt that Professor Nini was “very good at explaining course concepts and providing interesting contexts.”  One of these students said that Professor Nini “did a good job of generating student participation” and another appreciated that “he covered more material than the other two modules did.”  The fourth student felt that Professor Nini’s module was “the weakest,” but still found Professor Nini’s “fill-in style of notes effective at keeping the students’ attention.”  This student also commented that all the professors “were prepared for class and knew their material.”

Grading for the class is based entirely on three exams.  There is one exam per module and the exams are not cumulative.  There are no prerequisites.  INSR 205 fulfills the Organizational Environment requirement for Wharton undergrads.

Insurance 205 describes the concepts and techniques available to corporations, non-profit organizations, and other organizations in their efforts to manage pure risks. The costs associated with such pure risks as product liability, environmental impairments, property losses, work-related injuries, and employee benefits (e.g., pensions, health insurance, etc.) affect the daily management of organizations. Managers who make decisions without appropriate consideration of risk management issues can jeopardize the long-term survival of their organizations. The course examines a common set of techniques which can be used by managers in dealing with these problems, including risk assumption, prevention, diversification, and transfer via insurance and non-insurance market mechanisms. In turn, students learn to recognize that the institutional structure of the organization itself influence its own risks and their corresponding treatments.  The course is divided into three modules entitled The Theory of Risk, Human Capital R=isk Management, and Corporate Risk Management.  Each section is taught by a different professor.

Most students felt that the course was “good.”  Several highlighted the overlap between INSR 205 and finance, microeconomics, and math courses that they had already taken.   Of these students, most disliked the repetition and felt that it would be better to “cut these repeated topics out and instead add unique material.” Students generally liked the modular format and having “three different professors to mix things up.”  A few students mentioned that the course was “quantitative” and “problem-based.”

Professor Kartasheva taught model one.  The two students who commented specifically on Professor Kartasheva had very different opinions.  One felt that “Professor Kartasheva made a particular effort to engage the class,” while the other noted that Professor Kartasheva “rarely asked for audience participation.”  Additionally, while the first student appreciated that Professor Kartasheva “stuck with what was supposed to be taught,” the second said that “there were few similarities between the lecture notes on webCafe and what she taught in class.”  The first student also commented that all the professors “were prepared for class and knew their material.”

Grading for the class is based entirely on three exams.  There is one exam per module and the exams are not cumulative.  There are no prerequisites.  INSR 205 fulfills the Organizational Environment requirement for Wharton undergrads.
